part2.question:
Describe a time when the electricity suddenly went off where you live. You should say:
When it happened
How long it lasted
What you did during that time
And explain how you felt about it.
part2.model_answer: I'd like to describe a time when the power suddenly went out in my apartment complex. It happened last summer during a massive thunderstorm that shook the windows. It lasted for about four hours, leaving us completely In the dark [蒙在鼓里] without any air conditioning. I felt extremely Frustrated [沮丧的] and Helpless [无助的] because I had an Urgent [紧急的] assignment due the next morning that I hadn't finished. Without electricity, I couldn't use my computer or charge my phone, which was incredibly Inconvenient [不便的]. I ended up lighting some scented candles and reading a textbook by flickering candlelight until the power finally came back on late at night.

part2.question:
Describe an occasion when an important piece of equipment stopped working. You should say:
What the equipment was
When it happened
How it affected you
And explain how you solved the problem.
part2.model_answer: My laptop suddenly broke down right before a major presentation at school. It was an Unexpected [意想不到的] failure that happened last Monday morning when I tried to turn it on. I was panicked because all my slides and notes were stored on it. It affected me badly as I couldn't access my work or practice. To solve the problem, I borrowed a friend's computer and luckily managed to download a backup from the cloud just in time. My friend really helped Save the day [挽救局面] for me by lending me his device and helping me set it up quickly before class started.

part2.question:
Describe a time when you broke something by accident. You should say:
What the item was
How the accident happened
How you felt immediately after
And explain what you did to fix the situation.
part2.model_answer: I accidentally broke my mother's favorite porcelain vase while cleaning the living room. I was dusting the top shelf and clumsily knocked it over with my elbow. It shattered into small, sharp pieces on the wooden floor. I felt terrible and guilty immediately because I knew how much she loved that antique. To fix the situation, I carefully cleaned up the mess and then went to the store to buy a new one that looked similar, though nothing could truly replace the original Precious [宝贵的 (time)] item she cherished for so many years.

part3.question: When will equipment break normally? Why?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Equipment usually breaks due to normal Wear and tear [磨损] over an extended period of time. [Reason] Nothing lasts forever, and moving parts eventually degrade with constant use, friction, and heat. [Example] A car engine, for instance, needs regular maintenance or it will surely fail one day unexpectedly. [Extension] Proper care and servicing can extend the lifespan of any machine significantly, saving money.

part3.question: Do people buy a new one when something is broken, or repair it?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Nowadays, people tend to buy new things due to the pervasive Throwaway culture [用完即弃的文化] we live in. [Reason] It is often cheaper and easier to replace an item than to pay for expensive repairs. [Example] Fixing a smartphone screen can cost almost as much as buying a brand new phone. [Extension] This behavior is unfortunately bad for environmental Sustainability [可持续性] and global resource use.

part3.question: Which do you think is better for production: using machines or making things by hand?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Machines are better for mass Manufacturing [制造业] because of their incredible speed and consistency. [Reason] They can produce thousands of identical items quickly without getting tired or making human errors. [Example] Cars are built by robots on assembly lines for maximum efficiency and safety standards. [Extension] However, handmade goods have a unique Creativity [创造力 (solving problems)] and soul that machines cannot replicate easily.

part3.question: Does the place where you live often experience power cuts?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Fortunately, power cuts are very rare where I live thanks to high grid Reliability [可靠性]. [Reason] The infrastructure is well-maintained and modern, ensuring a steady supply for everyone in the city. [Example] We only experience outages during extreme weather events like typhoons or severe floods. [Extension] Constant electricity is essential for our daily lives and continuous economic Development [发展].

part3.question: Are modern societies too dependent on electricity and technology?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Yes, our Dependency [依赖] on technology is dangerously high in almost every aspect of modern life. [Reason] We rely on it for everything from communication to banking and transport daily. [Example] If the internet goes down, businesses stop and people panic immediately because they can't function. [Extension] We should remember the old saying, "Don't fix what isn't broken [没坏就别修 (多一事不如少一事)]," but also be prepared for failures.

part3.question: Is the "throwaway culture" (buying new instead of repairing) sustainable for the environment?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] No, the Throwaway culture [用完即弃的文化] is extremely harmful to the global environment in the long term. [Reason] It generates massive amounts of electronic waste that pollutes the earth and water sources. [Example] Planned Obsolescence [废弃] forces consumers to discard working devices prematurely for corporate profit. [Extension] We need to focus more on repair, reuse, and recycling urgently to save our planet.
